title: When will Ted Cruz drop out of the race for the Republican presidential nomination?
possible_answers: After the New York primary but before the Nebraska primary
After the Nebraska primary but before the California primary
After the California primary but before the Republican National Convention begins
Not before the Republican National Convention
correct_answer: After the New York primary but before the Nebraska primary
preds: Suspend versus drop out. I think technically he will not call himself "dropped out" until Trump locks up 1237.
Assuming suspending is the same thing as "dropping out."
Vanity apparently outlasted funding. Otherwise, why suspend?

Updating following Cruz's exit. This was one which hardly anyone was able to forecast correctly. In hindsight, it does seem predictable. Unlike Kasich, Cruz is not being directly funded/liked by the establishment and his utility was only that he could be useful in stopping Trump from getting to 1237. Now that it is no longer possible, his usefulness has ended and they are pitching in all on Kasich. I would be quite surprised if Kasich throws in the towel as well. This is his chance to show that he can consolidate better than Trump. If he shows any sign of doing that, we may yet get a contested convention. Still too early to go all in on Trump.  I will probably get a Brier of 2.0 on this. Guess our community is still not quite large enough to avoid group think. We probably need to have an active user base that is 10-20 times larger to get the required number of divergent voices. Will take some time to get there.

Cruz has withdrawn after losing Indiana. That was quite a surprise, as I thought he was determined to go all the way, even though it was obvious he was way behind. I had zero probability for this option! I guess that means the dreaded 2.000 Brier Score.

the issue here is the writing on the wall vs. Cruz' psychology. If he wants any future at all in the party he needs to drop out, lest some of his delegates switch to Trump in the small chance of a brokered convention. usually there is a trade in exchange for a dropout, but he is so disliked he may not get anything, in which case he has nothing to lose. He has shown a willingness to cut off his nose to spite his face, and this maybe another example. But he will lose Indiana, but is ahead on Nebraska right now, so my thought is he hangs on for Nebraska. and then a string of losses before California may make him finally give up.  Lots of factors in play and they are tough to weigh, but i have to believe (perhaps to my detriment as with Kasich) that rationality will win out.

The odds are against Sen. Cruz in the upcoming Indiana primary[1]. Might he drop out if he loses this winner-take-all contest? I hadn't thought so, but an article has me wondering. "Within the campaign, some are turning to the question of what’s next. One senior aide said there had been no discussion about dropping out before the final primary contests are held on June 7 but noted that Cruz wouldn’t be eager to prolong a campaign he was convinced he couldn’t win. Many top figures in the party are convinced that a loss on Tuesday would be, for all intents and purposes, the end of the road. “A Cruz loss in Indiana means lights out,” said Scott Reed, the chief political strategist for the U.S. Chamber of Commerce. “Game, set, match”"[2].  -- [1] http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/primary-forecast/indiana-republican/
[2] http://www.politico.com/story/2016/04/ted-cruz-campaign-nervous-222675#ixzz47QeraMdr

I don't think Ted Cruz will drop his nomination at all until he sees thru Indiana, Nebraska & West Virginia (127 delegates). Given Cruz & Kasich have teamed up together, at this point, Indiana seems to be anyone's game (especially with Kasich out), but the other two states seem to be going Trump's way for sure. In any case, I would assume that about 70-80 delegates go to Trump, the rest for simplicity go to Cruz. This will still mean Trump will be in the 1050-1100 range. Cruz may give up, but if he gets even one success in these three states, especially Indiana, he wouldn't. Not much changes after this primary as Oregon & Washington go to polls, which total up to 72 delegates. Even with that included, Trump may be in 1100-1125 range. In such scenario as well, Cruz wouldn't give up. At any rate, by this time Cruz would have come so far out, that he would likely hold on till the very end. P.S. Best case if Trump sweeps everything, he would stand at ~150-170 delegates more after these two brackets or around the 1150 mark, which if gets crossed, I think Ted Cruz might, just might, give up. Though, having gone all this way, he will most likely go till the very end. After California ++ primaries, Ted Cruz will be eliminated most definitely, and will bow out in all likelihood before the Convention takes place. Maths should ensure this. I don't think the scenario would reach the Convention. But even the improbable has a probability, so I allocate a small probability here.

After more discussion with @imoatama in the TC question, I decided to tweak my model by adding probability of DT getting 1237+ (26%) for the "dropping out questions", and using 1195+ (58% - moved higher due to error) for other questions. Results in these forecast changes.
Changing on basis of conversation with @imoatama

The most important input to my forecasts in the monkey cage challenge has been Trump's chances of getting 1237+ delegates. However, analysing my changes in forecasts so far two things have gone wrong:
	- I have been nowcasting rather than forecasting, ie overreacting to first Colorado and then New York
	- I just assumed 1237 was the hurdle. Taking the first error, I have now looked at every forthcoming primary (mainly based on the tools provided by 538 - http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/), and ended up consequently focusing solely on the races in Indiana and California, there aren't too many margin of error in the others. On the second error, I am making the new assumption that 1195 is better hurdle, as it should be possible for Trump to convince 43 of the unbound delegates (Pennsylvania could provide at least 20) to vote for him. I wouldn't argue if anyone said it was lower but I figured 1180-1210 is the right range. So going back to Indiana, because of its partial binary nature (wta 30 delegates) and its demographics, if it goes to Cruz, which I think it will, Trump may only get 9 votes which would mean he would need around 122 from California. If DT wins Indiana with say 39 delegates, then he would need around 93 from California. All that to say, and sorry for length, but the only way I can objectively remember "what was I thinking" is to write it down, that I have Trump at 42% to win 1195+ delegates, which results in the above change.

I've been too high on this. This question can be broken down a bit. 1) - will Trump get to 1237 delegates before the convention. Probability of this is maybe around 50%. If he doesn't, no way Cruz drops out.  2) if Trump does get to 1237, will Cruz actually drop out anyway? There's precedent for not doing so; Ron Paul in 2012. The most likely outcome of all this is that Trump falls just short of 1237, Cruz doesn't drop out, & Trump wins on the first ballot at the convention anyway.

I don't think Cruz will drop out unless he has to, but with Trump's NY win, I see him as fairly likely to secure the majority of delegates before the convention, forcing others to drop out. Most pundits disagree, but the delegate calculator makes it seem pretty possible - http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/can-you-get-trump-to-1237/

I'm guessing (going by news reports and interviews) that Cruz's strategy is to try to deny Trump from getting to the majority of delegates on the first ballot outright and then using the second through infinity ballots at the convention to try to get the nomination.  So the question is more what events could cause him to drop out.  My guess would be cash, a path to victory clearly cut off (not limited necessarily to Trump winning delegates outright), or a personal emergency. Well considering NY primary is today, that's not going to happen.  So I can cross that off the list. The easiest one is the personal emergency: Cruz is young and hale (by candidate standards).  His wife and kids seem healthy too (I can't see how anyone else getting sick or dying who would more than temporarily put him off his ambitions).  I suppose a truck could run over Cruz or something.  Any American's chance in a given year of dying by accident (general accidents, cars, pedestrians, and I'm lobbing in firearmed murder for good measure) is around .06%.  I'm guessing Cruz's chance of that is lower, and even if we doubled his chance of dying in a year to account for the possibility he gets a heart attack, given there's only a quarter of a year left until the convention, that's still way less than 1%. So let's turn to cash.  As of Feb, Ted Cruz has 8 mil cash on hand.  His burn rate even in Feb was just 88%.  Plus (I know it doesn't pay staff expenses) he has 53 odd mil in super pac cash.  He has about 20 days to go before Neb.  And around 45 or so days before California and 89 days until the convention (but after CA, he could probably put a hold on a lot of staff costs).  I'm no expert on campaign finance, but I doubt he'll run out of money.  If I had more time, I would probably try to see how much money other folks had on hand in the past at a similar point in the race to better calibrate how likely he is to run out of money. The only remaining reason to cause Cruz to drop out then is if the path to viability is closed to him.  Cruz has a fantastic ground operation as shown by his delegate pickups in Wyoming and Colorado.  He's focusing hard not so much on winning the remaining states outright (of which his chances are quite low given their favorable demographic and polling advantages for Trump) but rather to decide which individual delegates are sent regardless of who they're (momentarily) bound to.  Trump's staffing rearrangements change this dynamic somewhat since his new staff is much better experienced at securing delegates, but Cruz's team has a time spent advantage over them.  And while actors in DC hate Cruz, grassroots conservatives (the same ones that empowered his grandstanding shutdown in '13 by putting fear in the hearts of his colleagues) generally really like him and are probably more likely to end up in his hand-selected delegate slots.  In other words, Cruz could have an advantage in the rules committee to decide whether or not his delegates are even bound to Trump even on the first ballot.  Those delegates are also less likely to abandon him in favor of an "establishment outsider" dark horse.  More importantly, they can give Cruz a massive, friendly platform so that even if the party nominates Trump, Cruz is seen as the natural successor and defender of conservative values vs. Trump's constituents' values to run again in 4 or 8 years (which is by now what I suspect Cruz wants even more: a divisive floor fight where Trump loses might sink Cruz's general election chances) (The field after all is largely, (quite possibly permanently) cleared of other Tea Party darlings like Rubio, Jindal, Walker, and Brownback.  If anything, Cruz's enemy at the convention isn't Trump, it's Paul Ryan since both would be jostling for a future run).  Cruz could pick up platform concessions, party loyalty, even a prominent position in campaigning (or god forbid an administration) all in return for looking like the man who brought party unity.  And if the House and Senate get purged in the meantime, so much better for Cruz so he can continue his one-man obstructionism without having to try to govern. So the only reason to drop out between CA and the convention would be if it were an embarrassment to even show up to the convention (and even then, the aforementioned advantages in his loyal delegates would provide some incentive to anyway).  He probably wouldn't be dinged by the conservative activist base for trying to contest even a "locked" convention through the rules committee: after all plenty of them are calling for such maneuvers as a way to salvage House and Senate races.  Upshot has the chance that Trump wins with an outright majority of delegates after CA is a little over 50%.  538's consensus of experts puts the consensus average at a little below an outright majority.  It doesn't seem likely that Trump will blow Cruz away (though I will revise this as we see how good or bad Cruz's delegate game is vs. Trump's).  And every incentive exists for Cruz to make himself known at the convention even if his strategy to get the nomination is closed off.

Practically no reason beyond death to drop out before California. Donald Trump is looking less and less likely to reach the delegate threshold, but still has a very reasonable chance of getting there (c30-50%), according to most betting markets and also all our predictions (based on the consensus forecast on a brokered convention, nobody else can reach a yes vote on the first round realistically). My rationale is the following_ Ted Cruz will only drop out of the race if Trump gets the majority of delegates. So we have to analyze how likely Trump is getting the 1237 delegates he needs to at every stage of the bet.

In order to help me with my analysis I go to 538's models  (http://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/election-2016/delegate-targets/ ). Some notes on this model: - Until now it has been quite accurate in predicting the number of delegates for Donald Trump. 
- The model doesn't predict that Trump will get his majority before California. So my conclusions from the analysis of 538: a) Donald Trump will not get his 1237 delegates before California
b) Even with the errors that may occur in the model it is very likely that Trump will get his delegates before the Convention.   So below follows my forecast: NY- 0%
NEB- 0%
CA- 0%
CONV- 70%

As the only credible challenger to Trump, he's very likely to stay in the race through all of the remaining primaries.  However, Cruz will very likely be mathematically eliminated from reaching 1237 delegates through primaries sometime around the Nebraska primary.  At this point it becomes possible that he will make a deal with Trump.  There is a chance that Trump will secure 1237 delegates after the final primaries, in which case Cruz will very likely leave the race.  There is also some chance that Trump doesn't secure 1237 delegates, but makes a deal with Cruz before the convention.  While Cruz's personality may cause him to ignore political realities, there are several scenarios where dropping out will do more to further his career than staying in through the convention.

Why might Senator Cruz stay in the race until the convention begins? First, Sen. Cruz does have a chance of winning the nomination outright, though it can't be much higher than 0.02 at the moment[a]. Second, he's got 425 delegates, almost 2/3 as many as Mr. Trump[b]. And Sen. Cruz will pick up more along the way[c]. He might even win enough delegates in California[d] to deny Mr. Trump the ability to win 1,237 delegates before the Republican convention. Third, even if Sen. Cruz does not manage either to win the nomination before the end of the primaries or to deny Mr. Trump a majority of the delegates, it makes sense for him to be seen as in play for as long as possible. For he would be the most obvious beneficiary if Mr. Trump were forced to withdraw. And Mr. Trump will be 70 before the convention; no matter how good his health is supposed to be[e], that ain't young. Moreover, as @Anneinak points out, Cruz might yet receive a gift from the Republican Rules Committee[f].  So why might Sen. Cruz leave the race before the convention? One possibility is some sort of debilitating scandal arises. Another is ill health, either his own or that of one of his family members. Without much evidence, I think that these are very low probability events. Yet another possibility is an utterly humiliating loss, a la Marco Rubio in Florida. But Sen. Cruz has already won his home state (handily), and a bad loss (in, say, Utah) would sting but would probably be forgotten in the next news cycle. The only serious obstacle I can see in the possibility of running out of money, and that doesn't seem likely. Cruz has $13.6 million on hand[g]. That's almost as much as Bernie, and nearly an order of magnitude more than Governor John Kasich. So I think Sen. Cruz is in it to the end, bitter or not. -- [a] http://www.motherjones.com/politics/2016/03/ted-cruz-narrow-path-nomination [b]http://www.realclearpolitics.com/epolls/2016/president/republican_delegate_count.html [c] http://www.nytimes.com/2016/03/23/us/politics/election-results-preview.html [d] http://www.redstate.com/leon_h_wolf/2016/03/10/new-poll-shows-cruz-likely-beat-trump-heads-california/ [e] http://www.cnn.com/2015/12/14/politics/donald-trump-medical-bill-health/ [f] https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/184659 [g] http://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2016/us/elections/election-2016-campaign-money-race.html

Cruz will be well behind Trump in delegate count, but the Party seems to want him to stay in at this point. Cruz could drop out if Trump has the 1237 delegates needed for the nomination after California, but I don't think either candidate will have that many.

There's simply no reason for Cruz to drop out prior to New York. Losing in Wisconsin would be disappointing but far from fatal. 
New York is the first big hurdle, but Cruz is polling poorly there and Trump winning all of the delegates wouldn't make a big difference because it's more-or-less expected at this point. After New York, there isn't an obvious path for Trump to the 1,237 delegates needed to clinch the nomination until California; I favour leaving tiny margins for the unexpected but it's hard to imagine a plausible combination of results which would knock Cruz out of the race.
That makes June 7 (the date of the California primary and the rest of the final Republican primaries) crucial. If Trump has passed the 1,237 delegate threshold on that date, or secures enough unattached delegates to make it between that date and the convention, there's no point in Cruz going on. It really could go either way at this point; I'd give Trump slightly better than even odds and that reflects in the final two scores.

The NY primary is the next large delegate haul, but Cruz and his supporters are likely to dismiss any NY results as homefield advantage.  The next big turning point is likely to be CA. Trump will take Arizona, North Dakota, Wisconsin, New York, Maryland, Pennsylvania, California, New Jersey, Delaware, Rhode Island, West Virginia, New Mexico  and probably Connecticut, Indiana. Cruz will take Utah, Wyoming, maybe Oregon. Arizona, New Jersey, Delaware, Nebraska, South Dakota are winner-take-all. North Dakota, Wisconsin, Connecticut, Utah are proportional with a 15% mandatory minimum. Rhode Island is proportional with a 10% minimum. New York, Pennsylvania, California, Indiana, Oregon are proportional-more-complicated. Maryland, New Mexico are proportional. West VA's district delegates are proportional, while at-large delegates are winner-take-all. Most Wyoming delegates are chosen at that state convention.  Trump will take all delegates in Arizona. Cruz might meet his goals in Utah, North Dakota, New York, and he already has in Wyoming. So I guess he's not dropping out before New York. He'll probably meet his goals in Pennsylvania, Maryland, Rhode Island, and Connecticut, but those are very modest goals. I don't know about Nebraska and Indiana, as there is no polling data. If he doesn't take all of Nebraska's delegates, I think he's out of the race. If Cruz continues, he is unlikely to meet his goals in West VA, which is another winner-take-all that he needs to win. He might win all delegates in South Dakota, as he hopes. I'm thinking the most delegates he can get is about 350 on top of the 424 he already has. 775 delegates does not seem enough to challenge Trump. If Trump misses in Indiana and Nebraska (he will in Nebraska), he will fall short of the 1237 delegates needed for the nomination, allowing Cruz to stay in the race until the end. The question is not really predictable at this point, as much hinges on whether Cruz wins big in Indiana and Nebraska. They're midwestern fundamentalist territory, his kind of place, but no recent polling data. It also depends on how badly the Republican party wants him to stay in the race and what the Stop-Trump campaign is cooking up.

- If a candidate thinks they have a 10% or more chance at the nomination, then they are at least 75% likely to stay in the race, especially if they see a clear path. 
- If Cruz gets to a contested convention, he puts his chances of attaining the nomination at 30% or better.
- Cruz can get to the convention if Trump gets less than 40% of remaining delegates. 
- Trump support maxes out around 40% of GOP voters. 
- Trump needs ~40% of the vote for the remaining states in order to attain enough delegates to get the nomination.
- The GOP is beginning to coalesce around Cruz despite being disliked. Establishment figures are likely to get behind Cruz:Trump at a 2:1 ratio at least. Establishment figures against Trump will repress Trump turnout from undecideds, meaning Trump won't break through his historical turnout levels. At the convention, establishment support will be viewed as assisting Cruz. 
- Nevertheless, there remains a chance that Trump reaches the delegates he needs for the nomination. That number is not very high, but if he reaches it, Cruz has to drop out by definition. 
- There's also a chance that some difficult to foresee reason causes Cruz to drop out before California. That might include a surprise deal with Trump, but that or any other imaginable outcome seem highly unlikely. Cruz wants to do his own thing.
- Question: what is the technical meaning of a "drop-out". Is that voluntary or also involuntary (i.e. Trump gets enough delegates to win the nomination before the convention)?
